prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N1365bar
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do mosaic on the stellar bar of the galaxy NGC1365 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=5 km/s. This is to make five sigma detection of H2 surface density of 20 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for a starburst/CMZ conversion factor alpha_co=1.6 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence should allow us to detect diffuse gas or smaller-than-beam clouds at lower-than-GMC mean surface density. This is also about 3 times deeper than our pilot SMA observations

The line width of 400 km/s is that of the entire galaxy. Molecular clouds in the mapping area individually have much smaller line widths. Those off the CMZ likely have total line widths as small as 5-10 km/s. The requested 1.5 km/s resoultion is to measure such line shapes and widths.

We do average 2-channels to reduce the data rate. The bright CMZ likely shows more lines than we target. Hence we cannot reduce our bandwidth. The reason for the channel width was given aboge. A unifrom channel widths across the SPWs is to simplify our data reduction. Also, in addition to CO(2-1) in SPW1, we have H30alpha in spw2, CS(5-4) in spw3, and CH3OH in spw4, though only CO is certain to be detected.

Angular resolution of 0.6" is the highest possible to survey multiple bars in CO(2-1) in a practical observing time.
The bar has a large extent of ~4 arcmin. It's thin width compared to its length and galactic rotation make the LAS about 100 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N1365cmz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a small mosaic on and around the CMZ of the galaxy NGC 1365 in CO(2-1)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=20 km/s. The larger velocity width for the same rms Tb as our larger mosaic is because molecular clouds in the CMZs are generally more turbulent than those in the disk, while having comparable or higher brightness temperature. The total line width of 100 km/s is possible for a clump [Sak07]. The rms sensitivity for a dV=100 km/s channel corresponds to rms mass surface density of 35 Msun/pc^2. Clouds with very high-surface densities of several 100 Msun/pc^2 across our 0.3" beam will be firmly detected and their parameters including line width can be measured with this sensitivity.

The line width of 400 km/s is that of the entire galaxy. Molecular clouds in the mapping area individually have much smaller line widths. Those (slightly) off the CMZ likely have total line widths as small as 5-10 km/s. The requested 1.5 km/s resoultion is to measure such line shapes and widths.

We do average 2-channels to reduce the data rate. The bright CMZ likely shows more lines than we target. Hence we cannot reduce our bandwidth. The reason for the channel width was given aboge. A unifrom channel widths across the SPWs is to simplify our data reduction. Also, in addition to CO(2-1) in SPW1, we have H30alpha in spw2, CS(5-4) in spw3, and CH3OH in spw4, though only CO is certain to be detected.

Angular resolution of 0.3" is the highest possible to survey multiple CMZs in CO(2-1) in a practical observing time.
We do mosaic to cover the CMZ area. However, we do not ask for ACA and/or TP because our primary target here is compact, CO luminous, cluster-forming clouds. If we later find a need for short baseline information for this 0.3" resolution data, we will manually combine our bar-mosaic data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83bar
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do mosaic on the stellar bar of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=5 km/s. This is to make five sigma detection of H2 surface density of 20 Msun/pc^2 in a 5 km/s channel for a starburst/CMZ conversion factor alpha_co=1.6 Msun/pc^2 (K km/s)^-1. The surface density is >~ 5 times lower than the typical mean surface density of GMCs in our Galaxy and hence should allow us to detect diffuse gas or smaller-than-beam clouds at lower-than-GMC mean surface density. This is also about 3 times deeper than our pilot SMA observations

The line width of 400 km/s is that of the entire galaxy. Molecular clouds in the mapping area individually have much smaller line widths. Those off the CMZ likely have total line widths as small as 5-10 km/s. The requested 1.5 km/s resoultion is to measure such line shapes and widths.

We do average 2-channels to reduce the data rate. The bright CMZ likely shows more lines than we target. Hence we cannot reduce our bandwidth. The reason for the channel width was given aboge. A unifrom channel widths across the SPWs is to simplify our data reduction. Also, in addition to CO(2-1) in SPW1, we have H30alpha in spw2, CS(5-4) in spw3, and CH3OH in spw4, though only CO is certain to be detected.

Angular resolution of 0.6" is the highest possible to survey multiple bars in CO(2-1) in a practical observing time.
The bar has a large extent of ~4 arcmin. It's thin width compared to its length and galactic rotation make the LAS about 100 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: M83cmz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will do a small mosaic on and around the CMZ of the galaxy M83 in CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our target sensitivity is sigma=0.5K for dV=20 km/s. The larger velocity width for the same rms Tb as our larger mosaic is because molecular clouds in the CMZs are generally more turbulent than those in the disk, while having comparable or higher brightness temperature. The total line width of 100 km/s is possible for a clump [Sak07]. The rms sensitivity for a dV=100 km/s channel corresponds to rms mass surface density of 35 Msun/pc^2. Clouds with very high-surface densities of several 100 Msun/pc^2 across our 0.3" beam will be firmly detected and their parameters including line width can be measured with this sensitivity.

The line width of 400 km/s is that of the entire galaxy. Molecular clouds in the mapping area individually have much smaller line widths. Those (slightly) off the CMZ likely have total line widths as small as 5-10 km/s. The requested 1.5 km/s resoultion is to measure such line shapes and widths.

We do average 2-channels to reduce the data rate. The bright CMZ likely shows more lines than we target. Hence we cannot reduce our bandwidth. The reason for the channel width was given aboge. A unifrom channel widths across the SPWs is to simplify our data reduction. Also, in addition to CO(2-1) in SPW1, we have H30alpha in spw2, CS(5-4) in spw3, and CH3OH in spw4, though only CO is certain to be detected.

Angular resolution of 0.3" is the highest possible to survey multiple CMZs in CO(2-1) in a practical observing time.
We do mosaic to cover the CMZ area. However, we do not ask for ACA and/or TP because our primary target here is compact, CO luminous, cluster-forming clouds. If we later find a need for short baseline information for this 0.3" resolution data, we will manually combine our bar-mosaic data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose subarcsec-resolution wide-field imaging of the entire stellar bars in two prototypical barred spiral galaxies. Our main goals are (1) the gas dynamics in bars to channel molecular gas to the central molecular zones (CMZs), and (2) ISM reactions to the bar-driven gas dynamics in the bars and in the star-forming CMZs including cloud formation leading to the formation of young massive clusters (YMCs). Our targets, M83 and NGC 1365, have face-on stellar bars of large ~4 arcmin extent on the sky. They will be fully mapped in CO(2-1) at linear resolutions of 10 and 50 pc, respectively, without missing any extended emission. Their CMZs will be imaged at twice higher resolutions through additional targeted observations. This project is going to reveal unprecedented details of the molecular gas behavior in galactic bars of moderate and large lengths (~5 and 20 kpc, respectively) and reveal the relation between gas dynamics, molecular cloud properties, and star cluster formation.
[This is a resubmission of our Rank B proposal. Our observations have been started but no data have been delivered yet.]

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University
